Executives have made it clear they're ready to ‚Äúgo to the mat‚Äù to fight, but that‚Äôs not how our economy or our democracy is supposed to work. Together, we‚Äôll close the revolving door and break the grip of giant corporations on our economy and our government.

If giant corporations violate these rules, they will have to pay up: 1% of net profits for the first violation, 2% for the second, and 5% for any subsequent violation. For a company like Facebook, that could mean over $1 billion.

Giant corporations shouldn't be able to rig the system by scooping up government officials to get favorable treatment. I'll ban giant federal contractors, banks, and market-dominant companies from hiring senior government officials for at least four years after they leave office.

It's not just Facebook. Giant corporations regularly hire people from their government regulators to leverage their connections and use the allure of future jobs to get favorable treatment. It‚Äôs no wonder these companies have consolidated power without any real accountability.
Facebook is now spending millions on lobbying amid antitrust scrutiny‚Äîand Kaplan is flexing his DC rolodex to help Mark Zuckerbeg wage a closed-door charm offensive with Republican lawmakers.

Two years after serving as George W. Bush‚Äôs Deputy Chief of Staff for Policy, Joel Kaplan was hired by Facebook as its Vice President for US Public Policy. Since he was hired, Facebook spent over $71 million on lobbying‚Äînearly 100 times what it had spent before Kaplan joined.

Giant market-dominant companies like Facebook, Pfizer, and Comcast strategically hire senior government officials who can leverage their contacts for corporate gain. If we want to root out Washington corruption, that must end‚Äîand I've got a plan. http://elizabethwarren.com/plans/break-monopoly-influence?source=soc-WB-ew-tw-rollout-20191029

ACERTs allow law enforcement and first responders to connect with local child specialists and professionals to intervene and mitigate the impacts of childhood trauma as soon as the scene is clear to begin making a difference.

Adverse Childhood Experiences, or ACEs, are events which have a heavy impact on the future wellbeing, success, or risk of violence of children. This bill would create ACE Response Teams (ACERTs) to deploy and provide services and care to children after these experiences.

Childhood trauma can have lifelong impacts on kids. I'm proud to join @SenatorShaheen in introducing legislation to provide crucial tools for law enforcement, first responders, and care providers to help ensure kids have bright futures after trauma.

We need to bring our laws into the 21st century & put people back in control of their personal data, because who knows where the internet will take us in another 50 years! That‚Äôs why I introduced the Information Transparency & Personal Data Control Act.
The most recent email privacy laws date back to the 1980‚Äôs, meaning there are more protections for letters in filing cabinets than emails in the cloud.

Now, 4.33 billion people are active internet users ‚Äì 56% of the global population ‚Äì and the internet does far more than it did 50 years ago. However, our laws regulating the internet are extremely outdated.

On Oct. 29th, 1969, Charles Kline sent some basic text from UCLA to the Stanford Research Institute via computer using a program called the Advanced Research Projects Agency Network (ARPANET). This was the start of the internet.
Since it‚Äôs the internet‚Äôs 50th birthday, let‚Äôs look back at how far we have come since its invention! *A Thread üëá*
